trans-unit.source: Writing Expressions for Attribute Mappings in Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Writing Expressions for Attribute Mappings in Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use expression mappings to transform attribute values into an acceptable format during automated provisioning of SaaS app objects in Azure Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use expression mappings to transform attribute values into an acceptable format during automated provisioning of SaaS app objects in Azure Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: When you configure provisioning to a SaaS application, one of the types of attribute mappings that you can specify is an expression mapping.
trans-unit.target: When you configure provisioning to a SaaS application, one of the types of attribute mappings that you can specify is an expression mapping.

trans-unit.source: For these, you must write a script-like expression that allows you to transform your users’ data into formats that are more acceptable for the SaaS application.
trans-unit.target: For these, you must write a script-like expression that allows you to transform your users’ data into formats that are more acceptable for the SaaS application.

trans-unit.source: The syntax for Expressions for Attribute Mappings is reminiscent of Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) functions.
trans-unit.target: The syntax for Expressions for Attribute Mappings is reminiscent of Visual Basic for Applications (VBA) functions.

trans-unit.source:
The entire expression must be defined in terms of functions, which consist of a name followed by arguments in parentheses:
FunctionName(<>,<>)
trans-unit.target:
The entire expression must be defined in terms of functions, which consist of a name followed by arguments in parentheses:
FunctionName(<>,<>)

trans-unit.source:
You may nest functions within each other. For example:
FunctionOne(FunctionTwo(<>))
trans-unit.target:
You may nest functions within each other. For example:
FunctionOne(FunctionTwo(<>))

trans-unit.source: You can pass three different types of arguments into functions:
trans-unit.target: You can pass three different types of arguments into functions:

trans-unit.source: Attributes, which must be enclosed in square square brackets.
trans-unit.target: Attributes, which must be enclosed in square square brackets.

trans-unit.source: String constants, which must be enclosed in double quotes.
trans-unit.target: String constants, which must be enclosed in double quotes.

trans-unit.source: Other Functions. For example: FunctionOne(<<argument1>>, FunctionTwo(<<argument2>>))
trans-unit.target: Other Functions. For example: FunctionOne(<<argument1>>, FunctionTwo(<<argument2>>))

trans-unit.source: For string constants, if you need a backslash ( \ ) or quotation mark ( " ) in the string, it must be escaped with the backslash ( \ ) symbol.
trans-unit.target: For string constants, if you need a backslash ( \ ) or quotation mark ( " ) in the string, it must be escaped with the backslash ( \ ) symbol.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Takes a source string value and appends the suffix to the end of it.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Takes a source string value and appends the suffix to the end of it.

trans-unit.source: Usually name of the attribute from the source object
trans-unit.target: Usually name of the attribute from the source object

trans-unit.source: The string that you want to append to the end of the source value.
trans-unit.target: The string that you want to append to the end of the source value.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Takes a date string from one format and converts it into a different format.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Takes a date string from one format and converts it into a different format.

trans-unit.source: Usually name of the attribute from the source object.
trans-unit.target: Usually name of the attribute from the source object.

trans-unit.source: Expected format of the source value.
trans-unit.target: Expected format of the source value.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Join() is similar to Append(), except that it can combine multiple source string values into a single string, and each value will be separated by a separator string.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Join() is similar to Append(), except that it can combine multiple source string values into a single string, and each value will be separated by a separator string.

trans-unit.source: If one of the source values is a multi-value attribute, then every value in that attribute will be joined together, separated the separator value.
trans-unit.target: If one of the source values is a multi-value attribute, then every value in that attribute will be joined together, separated the separator value.

trans-unit.source: String used to separate source values when they are concatenated into one string.
trans-unit.target: String used to separate source values when they are concatenated into one string.

trans-unit.source: Can be "" if no separator is required.
trans-unit.target: Can be "" if no separator is required.

trans-unit.source: String values to be joined together.
trans-unit.target: String values to be joined together.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Returns a substring of the source value. A substring is a string that contains only some of the characters from the source string.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Returns a substring of the source value. A substring is a string that contains only some of the characters from the source string.

trans-unit.source: Index in the source string where substring should start.
trans-unit.target: Index in the source string where substring should start.

trans-unit.source: First character in the string will have index of 1, second character will have index 2, and so on.
trans-unit.target: First character in the string will have index of 1, second character will have index 2, and so on.

trans-unit.source: If length ends outside the source string, function will return substring from start index till end of source string.
trans-unit.target: If length ends outside the source string, function will return substring from start index till end of source string.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Flips the boolean value of the source. If source value is "True", returns "False". Otherwise, returns "True".
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Flips the boolean value of the source. If source value is "True", returns "False". Otherwise, returns "True".

trans-unit.source:
Function:
ObsoleteReplace(source, oldValue, regexPattern, regexGroupName, replacementValue, replacementAttributeName, template)
trans-unit.target:
Function:
ObsoleteReplace(source, oldValue, regexPattern, regexGroupName, replacementValue, replacementAttributeName, template)

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Replaces values within a string. It works differently depending on the parameters provided:
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Replaces values within a string. It works differently depending on the parameters provided:

trans-unit.source: Replaces all occurrences of oldValue in the source with replacementValue
trans-unit.target: Replaces all occurrences of oldValue in the source with replacementValue

trans-unit.source: Replaces all occurrences of the oldValue in the template with the source value
trans-unit.target: Replaces all occurrences of the oldValue in the template with the source value

trans-unit.source: Replaces all values matching oldValueRegexPattern in the source string with replacementValue
trans-unit.target: Replaces all values matching oldValueRegexPattern in the source string with replacementValue

trans-unit.source: If source has no value, uses oldValueRegexPattern and oldValueRegexGroupName to extract replacement value from the property with replacementPropertyName.
trans-unit.target: If source has no value, uses oldValueRegexPattern and oldValueRegexGroupName to extract replacement value from the property with replacementPropertyName.

trans-unit.source: Replacement value is returned as the result
trans-unit.target: Replacement value is returned as the result

trans-unit.source: Usually name of the attribute from the source object.
trans-unit.target: Usually name of the attribute from the source object.

trans-unit.source: Value to be replaced in source or template.
trans-unit.target: Value to be replaced in source or template.

trans-unit.source: Regex pattern for the value to be replaced in source.
trans-unit.target: Regex pattern for the value to be replaced in source.

trans-unit.source: Or, when replacementPropertyName is used, pattern to extract value from replacement property.
trans-unit.target: Or, when replacementPropertyName is used, pattern to extract value from replacement property.

trans-unit.source: Only when replacementPropertyName is used, we will extract value of this group as replacementValue from replacement property.
trans-unit.target: Only when replacementPropertyName is used, we will extract value of this group as replacementValue from replacement property.

trans-unit.source: New value to replace old one with.
trans-unit.target: New value to replace old one with.

trans-unit.source: Name of the attribute to be used for replacement value, when source has no value.
trans-unit.target: Name of the attribute to be used for replacement value, when source has no value.

trans-unit.source: When template value is provided, we will look for oldValue inside the template and replace it with source value.
trans-unit.target: When template value is provided, we will look for oldValue inside the template and replace it with source value.

trans-unit.source:
Description:
Removes all space (" ") characters from the source string.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
Removes all space (" ") characters from the source string.

trans-unit.source:
Function:
Switch(source, defaultValue, key1, value1, key2, value2, …)
trans-unit.target:
Function:
Switch(source, defaultValue, key1, value1, key2, value2, …)

trans-unit.source:
Description:
When source value matches a key, returns value for that key. If source value doesn't match any keys, returns defaultValue. Key and value parameters must always come in pairs. The function always expects an even number of parameters.
trans-unit.target:
Description:
When source value matches a key, returns value for that key. If source value doesn't match any keys, returns defaultValue. Key and value parameters must always come in pairs. The function always expects an even number of parameters.

trans-unit.source: Default value to be used when source doesn't match any keys.
trans-unit.target: Default value to be used when source doesn't match any keys.

trans-unit.source: Replacement value for the source matching the key.
trans-unit.target: Replacement value for the source matching the key.

trans-unit.source:
You need to strip a known domain name from a user’s email to obtain a user name.
For example, if the domain is "contoso.com", then you could use the following expression:
trans-unit.target:
You need to strip a known domain name from a user’s email to obtain a user name.
For example, if the domain is "contoso.com", then you could use the following expression:

trans-unit.source: If you are using a Salesforce Sandbox, you might need to append an additional suffix to all your user names before synchronizing them.
trans-unit.target: If you are using a Salesforce Sandbox, you might need to append an additional suffix to all your user names before synchronizing them.

trans-unit.source: You need to generate a user alias by taking first 3 letters of user's first name and first 5 letters of user's last name.
trans-unit.target: You need to generate a user alias by taking first 3 letters of user's first name and first 5 letters of user's last name.

trans-unit.source:
You want to send dates to a SaaS application in a certain format.
For example, you want to format dates for ServiceNow.
trans-unit.target:
You want to send dates to a SaaS application in a certain format.
For example, you want to format dates for ServiceNow.

trans-unit.source:
You need to define the time zone of the user based on the state code stored in Azure AD.
If the state code doesn't match any of the predefined options, use default value of "Australia/Sydney".
trans-unit.target:
You need to define the time zone of the user based on the state code stored in Azure AD.
If the state code doesn't match any of the predefined options, use default value of "Australia/Sydney".
